refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: The aq add static route command defines a new static route.

The route definition is bound to the network containing the gateway address GW. If an interface of a machine has an address on the same network, then it will automatically inherit the route definition.

The destination range specified by IP and either MASK or PREFIX does not have to point to a network that exists in the database. For performance reasons, it is possible to add a single route that covers multiple networks.
Note that this command does not update the profiles of affected hosts. You have to run the aq make for all affected hosts.
If GW is the default gateway of a host, then the static route definition will be omitted from the plenary template, but the aq show host command will still display the static route.

listitem.para: IP address of the gateway that will route the traffic to the destination. The address must be part of a network that is already defined in the database.
IP address of the network that this static route is being created on. The gateway address will be infered from either a router address, or gatwway offset for this network.
Address of the destination range. Together with --netmask or --prefixlen, it defines the destination IP address range which should be routed through GW.
Define the netmask of the destination either as a dotted quad using --netmask, or as a prefix length using --prefixlen.
Defines the network environment where this route is valid. The default is defined by the default_network_environment key in the site section of the broker's configuration.
Name of a personality. If specified the static route will only be applied to hosts of the supplied personality.
Select the stage of the personality to use. Defaults to next.
Name of an archetype. If --personality is used, then this option is used as a qualifier to select the right archetype if the name of the personality is not unique.

example.title: Add a static route
example.para: Assuming the network 192.168.0.0/24 is already defined, the above command causes any hosts that have an IP address in network 192.168.0.0/24 to route all traffic destined to 192.168.1.0/24 through gateway 192.168.0.1.

E.g. if on some host the eth1 interface has address 192.168.0.10, then the following command (or its equivalent) will be executed on the host:
ip route add 192.168.1.0/24 via 192.168.0.1 dev eth1
